text: (bright upbeat music)
(bright music)

- What I'm looking for
first is I'm looking

to make sure that the wires
are in the right order.
My philosophy is,
"Let's throw you in the deep end
"and let's see what you're capable of."
That first day of class

is just always a day
that I look forward to

because I'm gonna be
meeting these students
that I'm gonna get to know.
What I love about teaching
is seeing that spark from my students.
If it's going right,
I'm learning something from the students
and they're asking me questions
that I don't know the answer to.
(bright music)
We created this program
in partnership with Amazon Web Services.
Amazon came to us and they said,

"We expect over the
next three to five years

"that we're gonna be
hiring a ton of technicians
"for our data centers."
I wanted to design this program
so that it would prepare students

to work in these jobs
as best as I knew how

and that we were
designing it for the tasks

they would actually perform
on the job in a as practical
and pragmatical way as possible.

What they wanna have is something
that they find meaningful

where they have some chance
to advance themselves,

not just in their career,
but in their lives.
So for the last few years,
AWS has very generously funded a total

of $50,000 of scholarships
for all of our students.

And this last year, they
doubled that scholarship amount.
So that's a total of $100,000
split between all of our students.

- I heard about this
program through my father.
So I gave it a shot.
I didn't really have a lot of hardware
or networking experience.

And so it was sort of like
drinking from a fire hose,

but they made it a little
bit easier to understand.
Pete was one of my instructors.

Me and Taylor were in the
same course or the same year.
From what I've seen,

everybody but one person
in our group that completed

the program has ended up
in some sort of IT role.
(gentle music)
- Do you think anything from the program
helped you get where you are right now?
- Oh, yeah.
None of it would've ever been possible
without going through the program.

It kept me focused on learning
more and more about tech.
And you and I would've never talked
to each other outside of that.
And now, we're coworkers.

- The most valuable thing
that I think I got from it

was how much Pete talked
about meeting people
and the attention we put on interviewing.
Because a lot of times, people ask,
"Could you help me get a job?"
(gentle music)

- One of the things about
going in a data center

is just seeing the extraordinary
scale that AWS works at.
It's almost just boggles the mind.

A couple years ago, I
was taking a sabbatical.
And I thought,
"Well,
"I need to make sure that I actually know
"what goes on in a data center."

And so I went to work
as a contract employee

at a "foot in the door job"
that many of our students get.

And it reaffirmed my commitment
to teaching hands-on skills.

- Pete would be great at
our job, hands down, right,
but he doesn't wanna do our job.
He wants to be a teacher.

- No, he's an interesting
(speakers crosstalk)
and talented person to be able

to take all of those
different personalities,

and different skillsets,
different backgrounds,
and help them all succeed.
- I can't imagine what the program
would look like without Pete.
- Hearing about your success,

it's always one of the
best parts of doing this.
- It's been a pretty cool journey

to go from not knowing
what a data center was,
not knowing much about fit hardware,
or software aspects of IT,
and then have a somewhat successful career
given my experience and education.

- My advice to you is
just to stick with this.
There are parts of this program
that I know for sure will really be tough.
(upbeat music)
So there's that assignment.
It's due today.
- This is like a month into the course.
And now, I'm kinda panicking.
Like, "Oh my gosh, am I gonna pass?
"Am I gonna get a job with Amazon?"
In the end,
I'm just trying to stick with it
and just focus on what I gotta do.

I think it's a great
opportunity to start a career.
And now that I've heard about it,
I've been kinda telling people,

"Hey, if you guys are
looking for something to do,
"you should come check this out."

- I was going to school here
originally in the medical field
and then I've seen flyers around.

The whole class experience,
it's been challenging,
and I like the challenge.
Anytime I can accomplish something,
it's been like, "I did that."
(gentle music)
- I remember one student, he would say,
"What I really want is just a career
"that's gonna make my family proud."

And he had a couple
young kids at the time.
And I ran into him at the data center.

He had gone from a dead-end
job to really a career

where he had achieved
what he'd set out to do.
And so for me,

(giggles) and I'm sorry this
is such an emotional topic,

but that for me is what
this work is all about.
(gentle music)

So when I think about
students who achieve that
and that's what I'm most proud of.
(gentle music)
